article_text:
A son wept over the body of his father in the middle of the wreckage of a missile attack in a residential district in the eastern Ukrainian town of Chuhuiv in the Kharkiv region as the country woke up on Thursday to an invasion ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin.

“I told him to leave,” the man in his 30s said, sobbing next to the twisted ruins of a car.

Nearby, a woman screamed curses into the wintry sky.

A missile crater, 4-5 metres (13-16 feet) wide, was scoured into the earth between two devastated five-floor residential buildings.

Firefighters battled to extinguish the blaze in the remnants.

Teenager Anastasia clutched her grey cat as she watched her grandfather in a wheelchair being loaded onto a minibus waiting to rush them to a nearby village.

Several other buildings on the street were damaged badly, their windows shattered and doorframes hanging in the frigid morning air.

It was among the first reported damage after Russia launched the invasion, with explosions heard in several locations across the country.

A policeman said the casualties from the bombardment were still being “evaluated”.

KYIV – Cities across Ukraine are under siege from Russian forces as they continue their assault on the country with “heavy casualties” reported on both sides.

Russian forces are continuing to advance towards the capital city of Kyiv as Mr Putin’s military continues its invasion on multiple fronts. According to a US defence official, Russia launched 160 missiles against Ukraine as of Thursday night.

Airports and military bases have been targeted in Russian rocket and drone strikes, while tanks are being used to fight the country’s border forces.

Late on Thursday Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky ordered a “general mobilisation” of the country’s men into the military.

He said 137 people had been killed in the first day of fighting, with hundreds more wounded.

Some 15 miles from Kyiv, fierce fighting raged for control of an airport as Ukrainian forces tried to stop Russia’s advance on the capital. People living in the town of Hostomel spoke of an intense air assault operation nearby Antonov Airport.

A former Ukrainian Government official announced later on Thursday afternoon that twenty Russian KA-52 and Mi-8 helicopters had landed at the Hostomel airfield, and said that fighting was ongoing.

Further reports suggested Ivano-Frankivsk International Airport, a civilian airport in western Ukraine, had also been hit, while pictures have emerged of emergency workers at the site of a Ukrainian military plane crash south of Kyiv.

According to the AFP news agency, 14 people were aboard the plane and the emergency service said it was “still determining how many people died.” The incident occurred about 12 miles south of capital city. Russia said it has suppressed Ukraine’s air defence capabilities with its attacks.

Videos shared by reporters on the ground also showed smoke rising above a military airfield near Chuguev in Kharkiv, in the east of Ukraine, where bloodied civilians were earlier pictured following shelling on an apartment block.

According to Ukraine’s National Police, Russian forces have also managed to capture the island of Zmiinyi in the Black Sea, which plays a key role in delimiting Ukraine’s territorial waters.

Military helicopters – thought to be Russian – fly over the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine, in this photo taken from video released by Ukrainian Police Department Press Service. (Photo: AP)

But a briefing from the Government’s Ministry of Defence department said: “The Ukrainian Armed Forces have put up a staunch resistance and continue to hold key cities.”

The statement added: “Heavy casualties have been suffered on both sides, although exact numbers are currently unclear.”

Chernobyl nuclear power plant has been captured by Russian forces, according to an adviser to the Ukrainian presidential office cited by Reuters.

There are growing concerns that the plant could be hit during fighting, releasing radioactive pollution across Europe.

President Zelensky had previously said that Russian forces were “trying to seize the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant” and indicated that Ukrainians had died today trying to defend it, saying: “Our defenders are giving their lives so that the tragedy of 1986 will not be repeated.”

“This is a declaration of war against the whole of Europe,” he said.

Mariana Bezuhla, a Ukrainian politician, also reported on Facebook that Russians were threatening to shell the nuclear plant Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.

US President Joe Biden announced sweeping export restrictions against Russia on Thursday in a fresh round of sanctions, hammering its access to global exports of everything from commercial electronics and computers to semiconductors and aircraft parts.

In a speech at the White House announcing the new controls, President Biden said they would “impose severe costs on the Russian economy both immediately and over time,” noting that allies including 27 members of the European union such as France, Germany and Italy as well as the UK Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand had joined in the response to maximise its impact. He also said targeting Mr Putin directly “was on the table”.

“This is a premeditated attack,” Mr Biden said, adding Mr Putin had refused efforts by the West to engage in dialogue and had violated international law.

“Putin is the aggressor. Putin chose this war. And now he and his country will bear the consequences.” Mr Biden also said Nato is as united as ever while reiterating it had no intention of intervening in Ukraine.

He added he believes the invasion is “unlikely” to last a long time “as long as we are resolved on sanctions” against Russia, which Mr Biden said is trying to rebuild the Soviet Union.

The EU also announced a fresh set of sanctions, with the 27-member bloc agreeing to freeze Russian assets in the bloc and halt banks’ access to European financial markets as part of what its foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell, described as “the harshest package of sanctions we have ever implemented”.

It will also target Russia’s trade, energy and transport, among other sectors, and impose export controls. The EU will also prepare a new aid package for Ukraine and new sanctions against Belarus.

Meanwhile, the Ukrainian ambassador to the US has claimed that one Russian platoon from Kemerovo, 74th Motorized Brigade, has surrendered to Ukrainian forces, saying they had not realised they were being sent to fight Ukrainians.

Ukraine’s military also said it had shot down five Russian jets and a helicopter, thought to have troops onboard, but Russia denied this.

Smoke rises as a fire burns on the premises of the Ukrainian Defence Ministry’s unit, in Kyiv, in this screen grab taken from a live video. There are suspicions it could be caused by the burning of documents. (Photo: Reuters TV)

Emergency personnel work at the crash site of a Ukrainian military plane south of Kyiv (Photo: AFP)

Airport battle

Fierce fighting raged for control of an airport just 15 miles from Kyiv as Ukraine tried to stop Russia’s advance on the capital. People living in the town of Hostomel spoke of an intense air assault operation nearby Antonov Airport.

One resident said Ukrainian ground forces had been targeted by fighter jets, as video footage showed Russian Mi-8 helicopters flying towards the airport. A CNN camera crew captured the moment Russian airborne troops surrounded the airport, which is a key cargo and military base.

By Thursday afternoon, it was reported that Russian forces had gained control. But in a televised address, President Volodymyr Zelensky vowed Ukrainian forces would retake the airport and had been given an order to “destroy” Russian troops. Civilian Alexander Kovtonenko, 30, also living nearby, said two fighter jets had shot missiles at Ukrainian ground units as the assault got underway.

“Then there was shooting, it lasted three hours,” he told AFP. “Then three more jets flew in and they started shooting again.” The battle was still raging at 10.30pm local time.

Ukraine President issues calls to arms

Earlier on Thursday, Mr Zelensky issued a call to arms to the Ukrainian people and that weapons would be given to anyone willing to fight.

During a broadcast to the nation he also appealed for blood donations for wounded soldiers.

“We are defending our country, we fight for our country and we protect our country,” Mr Zelensky said.

“We will give weapons to anyone who wants to defend the country. Be ready to support Ukraine in the squares of our cities,” he later tweeted.

Oleksiy Reznikov, Ukraine’s Defence Minister, has urged those willing to fight to join the ranks of the territorial defence forces.

On Wednesday, Ukraine said it was conscripting citizens aged 18-60 to its army reservists and gave permission for all civilians to carry firearms.

Mr Zelensky’s call to arms came as Ukrainians began fleeing the country with roads gridlocked, underground train stations packed and queues at bus stops, petrol stations and cash machines.

i correspondent David Parsley also reported seeing fires burning around Government buildings in what observers suspect is the destroying of documents.

See more Chuguyev military airfield, Kharkiv region: pic.twitter.com/REHCiZYODu — Michael Weiss (@michaeldweiss) February 24, 2022

Neighbouring Moldova and Lithuania have both declared states of emergency, with Lithuanian President Gitanas Nausėda warning that Russia’s “unprovoked military aggression” threatens “millions of innocent lives and undermines the foundations of international order.”

Meanwhile, the Czech Republic has closed two Russian consulates as well as the Czech consulate in Russia, Reuters reported.

Nato agrees action as civilian casualties confirmed

Nato envoys have agreed to strengthen air, land and sea forces on the alliance’s eastern flank near Ukraine and Russia.

The alliance said it had “increased the readiness of our forces to respond to all contingencies” and warned its members stood “united to defend each other.”

While some of Nato’s 30 member countries are supplying arms, ammunition and other equipment to Ukraine, the alliance itself has so far said it will not launch any military action to support Ukraine.

Poland’s health ministry said the country was preparing a medical train to transport Ukrainians wounded in Russia’s assault on its neighbour, adding that Polish hospitals were ready to receive thousands of patients.

A wounded woman after an airstrike damaged an apartment complex in city of Chuhuiv, Kharkiv Oblast, Ukraine (Photo: Wolfgang Schwan/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

Black smoke could be seen rising from the military airport in Chuguyev near Kharkiv on Monday morning. (Photo: Aris Messinis / AFP)

A gridlocked road in the capital of Kyiv as residents attempt to flee the city. (Photo: Pierre Crom/Getty Images)

The young boy reported to have been killed is said to have died during shelling on an apartment block in Chuguev, Kharkiv.

Another civilian was pictured with a bloodied face and bandage wrapped around her head after the apartment complex was hit.

Three border guards are also among the casualties recorded in Ukraine, the country’s border force said.

Amnesty International said on Thursday afternoon that it had also verified a ballistic missile strike outside a hospital in Vuhledar, killing at least two civilians.

“Hospitals are protected under international humanitarian law, ballistic missiles should never be used in populated areas,” the organisation said.

The Red Cross announced it was responding to severe water shortages after fighting left several water stations and pipelines, serving more than one million people, out of order.

Maksym Dotsenko, director general of the Ukrainian Red Cross Society, said the charity was “deeply concerned for the safety of communities” and had launched an emergency crisis appeal.

Explosions heard across Ukrainian cities

Mr Putin launched his attacks in a nationwide offensive in the early hours of Thursday using land, sea and air forces.

Explosions were heard in cities across the country, including in the capital Kyiv, in Kharkiv in the north-east, Odessa in the south, and eastern Donetsk Oblast.

At least 18 people were killed in a missile attack on the port city of Odessa, according to regional authorities, while the mayor of Brovary said that six people had been killed in the city.

A man stands in the aftermath of Russian shelling in Kyiv, Ukraine, 24 February 2022. (Photo: AP/ Efrem Lukatsky)

A woman cleans up broken glass after Russian shelling in Kyiv, Ukraine, 24 February 2022. (Photo: AP/ Efrem Lukatsky)

Sightings of Russian troop landings were also reported in Mariupol and Odessa on the southern coast.

Air raid sirens echoed across Kyiv and the western city of Lviv on Thursday morning, as the threat of all-out war hung over Europe for the first time in decades.

i‘s David Parsley reported that schools, and many of the shops and restaurants, were shut, with martial law declared as sirens sounded at 7am.

Nikoli, a translator, said he had got his family packed up and 400 miles away, far into the countryside, two nights ago. “I could see what was going to happen,” he said. “If I hadn’t got my family away then I wouldn’t be here now.”

Shelling also began in the Ukrainian villages of Kopani and Kherson, where Ukrainian soldiers were engaged in battle.

Local news outlets reported a further attack in the Obolon area of Kyiv at around 10am GMT and Ukrainian armed forces could be seen rolling into the area.

Putin claims he will ‘demilitarise and de-Nazify’ Ukraine

In a speech to the Russian nation on Thursday morning, President Putin announced his intention to “demilitarise and de-Nazify” his former Soviet neighbour. Mr Zelensky, Ukraine’s President, is Jewish.

“I have made the decision of a military operation,” Mr Putin said in an unannounced television address shortly before 6am in Moscow.

He cited, with no evidence, a “genocide” orchestrated by Ukraine in the country’s eastern provinces as reason for the attack, as well as Nato’s aggressive policy towards Russia – claims that Western leaders have dismissed.

“For this, we will strive to achieve demilitarisation and de-Nazification of Ukraine,” said Mr Putin.

He urged Ukrainian servicemen to “immediately put down arms and go home” saying he aimed to “demilitarise not occupy” the country.

In a stark warning to the wider world, Mr Putin said there would be “consequences” never seen before for any countries that wished to intervene.

“To anyone who would consider interfering from outside: If you do, you will face consequences greater than any you have faced in history. All the relevant decisions have been taken. I hope you hear me,” he said.

People look at the aftermath of shelling in a street in Kyiv on Monday morning. (Photo: Sergei Supinsky / AFP)

Firefighters work on a fire on a building after bombings on the eastern Ukraine town of Chuguev on February 24, 202 (Photo: ARIS MESSINIS/AFP via Getty Images)

Kyiv motorways gridlocked as residents flee

In the capital of Kyiv, the city’s motorways were gridlocked with people trying to flee.

Despite calls from the Ukrainian President to stay at home, people in Kyiv were scrambling to fill up their vehicles at petrol stations and stock up on supplies at supermarkets.

Residents were also seen withdrawing cash from ATMs and are understood to be purchasing firearms and ammunition.

But some sought shelter in basements and underground transport hubs as explosions rang out, with photographs showing people sitting together on the floor of metro stations.

Cars drive towards the exit of the city after Russian President Vladimir Putin authorised a military operation in eastern Ukraine, in Kyiv, Ukraine. (Photo: Valentyn Ogirenko/ Reuters)

People queue at an ATM after Putin announced the Ukrainian military offensive. (Photo: Reuters/ Valentyn Ogirenko)

Reporters have also filmed long queues of people waiting to give blood to treat Ukrainian soldiers in hospital, after Mr Zelensky called on the population to donate.

Flights in and out of Ukraine suspended

UK airlines have been instructed to avoid Ukrainian airspace until further notice, the Civil Aviation Authority said.

Airlines have suspended travel in and out of Ukraine this morning, with Ryanair halting all Ukrainian flights for the next fortnight.

“Due to the closure of Ukrainian airspace overnight and the apparent invasion by Russian forces, all Ryanair flights to/from Ukraine have been suspended for at least the next 14 days,” the airline said in a statement.

“All affected passengers will receive email notices later this morning and all flights to/from Ukraine have been removed from sale for at least the next four weeks until further information becomes available from EU safety agencies. ”

Wizz Air also announced it had “temporarily suspended” flight operations in Ukraine, adding: “The safety and security of our passengers and crew remains our number one priority and we hope normality will to return to Ukraine soon.”

Ukraine International Airlines, which links Gatwick Airport with Kyiv, also stopped flights to and from Ukraine, saying: “The UIA team takes all possible measures to ensure the safety of our passengers.”

Moldova announced it would close its airspace on Thursday and divert flights to other airports due to the security situation in the region.

World condemns attack and threatens further action

Ukraine has called on the rest of the world to support the country in the face of the Russian invasion, with the country’s official account tweeting: “Russia has started the new wave of aggression against Ukraine. Wherever you are and whatever you do, you can help Ukraine now.”

Boris Johnson said he was “appalled by the horrific events in Ukraine”, warning that “the UK and our allies will respond decisively”.

Mr Johnson confirmed he had spoken to President Zelensky to “discuss next steps”, while Foreign Secretary Liz Truss reportedly had a “heated” meeting with the Russia ambassador earlier today.

The Prime Minister made an address to the nation on the developments in Ukraine this morning and announced a raft of sanctions in the Commons that he said would “hobble” Russia’s economy.

Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, said the body would present a package of “massive and targeted sanctions” to European leaders for approval, with the focus on hitting “strategic sectors of the Russian economy” by blocking access to key technologies and markets.

The sanctions are due to be discussed at an emergency EU summit at 7pm GMT.

Ireland promised “very direct and very hard-hitting” sanctions against Russia, but confirmed that “we are not going to go to war with Russia, militarily.”

Germany’s foreign minister said that “we woke up in a different world today”, while French President Emmanuel Macron, who had been trying to negotiate a diplomatic solution, said that “France firmly condemns Russia’s decision to wage war” and promised support for Ukraine.

But China’s customs agency approved imports of wheat from all regions of Russia on Thursday – a move that could help to reduce the impact of possible Western sanctions.

Russian TV defending invasion

Russian TV channels – which are predominantly state owned – have been quoting a Russian Defence Ministry stressing that only “high-precision weapons” were being used in Ukraine and insisting there were no threats to civilians – despite reports and images of civilian casualties.

Official state Rossiya 1 TV began a news bulletin by saying: “Today Russia has begun a special military operation aimed at protecting the people who for the last eight years have been subjected to abuse and genocide by the regime in Kyiv.”

But opposition leader Alexei Navalny used a court hearing to condemn the invasion, accusing the Russian state of using the war with Ukraine as a distraction from internal problems.

‘The war with Ukraine has been unleashed to cover up the robbery of Russian citizens and divert their attention away from the country’s internal problems, from the degradation of its economy,” he said, according to Daily Mail US journalist Rob Crilly.

Invasion ‘could bring UK war with Russia’

A retired army officer has warned that the invasion could bring the UK to war with Russia.

General Sir Richard Shirreff warned that if Russia puts “one bootstep” into Nato territory, the entire alliance will be at war.

Asked if the UK might be expected to get involved directly in the conflict, he said: “Absolutely there is a possibility that we as a nation could be at war with Russia, because if Russia puts one bootstep across Nato territory, we are all at war with Russia. Every single one, every single member of the Nato alliance.

“Article 5 (of the Nato alliance) says an attack on one is an attack on all, so we need to change our mindset fundamentally, and that is why I say our defence starts in the UK on the frontiers of Nato.”

Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky said Thursday that Russia was attacking his country’s “military infrastructure” and border guards, but urged citizens not to panic and vowed victory.

Russia’s defense ministry said it had neutralized Ukrainian military airbases and its air defense systems, hours after Russian President Vladimir Putin launched a military offensive against his country’s neighbor.

“Military infrastructure at Ukrainian army air bases has been rendered out of action,” the defense ministry said in a statement carried by news agencies, which added that Kyiv’s air defense systems were “eliminated.”

Read more: Russian ground forces cross into Ukraine as death toll from shelling climbs

The ministry denied reports that its aircraft had been downed over Ukraine. Earlier, Ukraine’s military had said five Russian planes and one helicopter were shot down over its Luhansk region.

Watch: A video shows smoke billowing from a Ukrainian military airport in Chuguev as Russia says it has destroyed Ukraine airbases, air defenses.#RussiaUkraineConflict #RussiaUkraineCrisishttps://t.co/qbbNZVNgax pic.twitter.com/LxW05fgbE9 — Al Arabiya English (@AlArabiya_Eng) February 24, 2022

Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine said they had captured the towns of Shchastia and Stanytsia Luhanska in Ukraine’s region of Luhansk, the RIA news agency reported. There was no immediate comment by authorities in Ukraine.

Ukraine is coming under artillery attack along its northern border with Russia and Belarus, the country’s border guard service said on Thursday, adding that Ukrainian forces were returning fire.

The statement was issued as a Ukrainian interior ministry official reported the Ukrainian government-held town of Shchastya had fallen to Russian-backed eastern insurgents.

Ukraine’s border guards service said an attack is also taking place from Crimea, Reuters reported.

In a video message posted on Facebook after Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the launch of a military operation against Ukraine, Zelensky also introduced martial law across the country, adding that he had spoken by phone with US President Joe Biden.

Explosions rang out before dawn Thursday in Ukraine’s capital Kyiv and several cities near the frontline and along the country’s coasts.

AFP correspondents also heard blasts in the Black Sea port city of Odessa, close to the frontline of a Russian-backed rebel enclave and just across the sea from Russian-occupied Crimea.

Explosions also rang out in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, which lies 35 kilometres (20 miles) south of the Russian border and outside the eastern zone where Kyiv has been battling Moscow-backed insurgents since 2014.

Watch: The sound of Russian shelling can be heard in a video captured by a resident in Kharkiv’s Saltovka district in eastern Ukraine.#RussiaUkraineConflict #RussiaUkraineCrisishttps://t.co/qbbNZVNgax pic.twitter.com/wBZLaepbAd — Al Arabiya English (@AlArabiya_Eng) February 24, 2022

Ukraine closed its airspace to civilian planes, and Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba tweeted that his country was facing a “full-scale invasion”.

Closer to the eastern war zone, four loud blasts rang out in Kramatorsk, which serves as the Ukrainian government’s effective capital for the eastern war zone.

More blasts also rang out in Mariupol, a port on the Sea of Azov which provide a land bridge between Russia and the Kremlin-annexed Crimea peninsula.

“Russia’s offensive military operation is to destroy the Ukrainian state,” the foreign ministry said in a statement.

“Our defenders are ready to repel the aggressor state and will do everything in their power to defend Ukrainian land,” it added, calling on Ukraine’s Western allies to “immediately” impose new sanctions on Russia.

Insight

Russia's "military operation" has triggered chaos and fear in several parts of Ukraine, as sounds of warplanes and explosions grow louder.

As Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the launching of a "military operation" in Donbass in eastern Ukraine on Thursday morning, several reports of military convoys, missile strikes, explosions and people packing up their belongings in a bid to leave the sensitive areas started making rounds on the Internet.

While many journalists and regional experts urged media organisations to verify the visuals coming out of the region to avoid war mongering and escalating panic, here are some credible images portraying the current situation in the region.

Tanks and armoured vehicles of the Russian army began to be seen in Donetsk, while explosions started to be heard in Ukraine's various cities. (AP)

Explosions hit the cities of Kharkiv, Kramatorsk, Mariupol, Mykolaiv and Odessa at 04:50 local time. Ukrainians woke up to the sounds of bombings.

Black smoke that can be seen below rose from a military airport in Chuguev near Kharkiv, plunging Ukraine's morning into alarming darkness.

Explosions hit the cities of Kharkiv, Kramatorsk, Mariupol, Mykolaiv and Odessa at 04:50 local time. (AA)

The Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy ordered defending Ukraine, calling all citizens who were ready to defend the country from Russian forces to come forward, saying Kiev would issue weapons to everyone who wants them.

Meanwhile, Ukrainian soldiers were seen getting into a military vehicle in Mariupol with worried faces as Zelenskyy declared martial law.

Zelenskyy ordered defending Ukraine, calling everyone to defend the country. (AP)

Ukrainians who had long braced for the possibility of a Russian operation were urged to stay home and not to panic, while citizens began to line up in front of ATMs and banks to withdraw money as the conflict expected to harshly damage the country’s vulnerable economy.

Citizens began to line up in front of ATMs and banks to withdraw money. (Reuters)

While multiple explosions took place in the following hours, civilians started to leave their houses, even cities within the sound of sirens and military jets.

Many were panicked at the escalation of hostilities, lamenting on not knowing where to go or what to do while blasts hit their houses.

Many explosions took place as civilians started to leave their houses. (AA)

In eastern Ukraine, mortar fires by the separatist-controlled Donetsk damaged the Ukrainian-controlled areas, while the local people were shaken by fear.

Two of them are a woman and child, who peer out of the window of a bus as they leave Sievierodonetsk, the Luhansk region, eastern Ukraine.

Many were panicked at the escalation of hostilities, lamenting on not knowing where to go. (AP)

While some civilians are trying to leave the city, others are trying to escape possible bombs by taking shelter in subway stations and basements of their houses.

"I woke up because of the sounds of bombing. I packed a bag and tried to escape," told Maria Kashkoska, one of the residents who sheltered inside the Kiev metro station told the AFP news agency.

The picture below shows frightened Ukrainians a subway station after air raid sirens rang out across the country's main cities.

People take shelter in a subway station. (Reuters)

Russia's defence ministry declared that it has neutralised Ukrainian military airbases and its air defence systems.

Ukraine, on the other hand, stated that it has killed "around 50 Russian occupiers" while repulsing an attack on a town on the frontline with Moscow-backed rebels.

In the midst of these conflicts, an apartment in the city of Kharkiv was damaged and injured many, causing bloodshed and tears.

Here, you see one man grieving after a devastating explosion destroyed his building.

While some civilians are trying to leave the city, others are trying to escape possible bombs. (AFP)

World leaders swiftly condemned Russia's military attack, with Western capitals vowing to escalate sanctions against Moscow while the head of the United Nations demanded the conflict end immediately.

Big explosions were heard before dawn in Kiev. (AP)

But smokes and flames continue to rise in Ukrainian cities including in a military building in Kiev that can be seen above, signalling the continuation of conflict in spite of the devastating catastrophe.

It began before dawn. An assault on Ukraine. An assault on Europe.

After weeks of promising he meant this country no harm, Vladimir Putin finally gave the order to attack.

Within minutes targets had been hit all over. From airports in the west and south, to apartment blocks in the east. Rockets fired from inside Russia rained down on the outskirts of Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv.

Soon armoured columns crossed into the country from Crimea in the south and Belarus in the north. Moving swiftly, perhaps with the intention of cutting the country in two.

At an airport no more than 20 miles (32 km) from the centre of Kyiv, paratroopers arrived while it was still dark, quickly establishing a base that could be used to launch attacks on the capital.

Here in Kyiv, which has been so calm through recent weeks of this mounting crisis, there was shock, fear, and panic.

People sheltered underground, formed long queues at supermarkets and banks, and in many cases, got in their cars and tried to drive out, causing gridlock. At Kyiv’s bus station, young people looked for any way to leave.

KYIV/MARIUPOL, Ukraine, Feb 24 (Reuters) - Ukrainian forces battled Russian invaders on three sides on Thursday after Moscow unleashed the biggest attack on a European state since World War Two, prompting tens of thousands of people to flee their homes.

After Russian President Vladimir Putin declared war in a pre-dawn televised address, explosions and gunfire were heard through the day in Ukraine's capital and elsewhere in the country, with at least 70 people reported killed.

The assault brought a calamitous end to weeks of fruitless diplomatic efforts by Western leaders to avert war over Russian demands for a redrawing of post-Cold War security arrangements in Europe.

"This is a premeditated attack," U.S. President Joe Biden told reporters at the White House as he unveiled harsh new sanctions, coordinated with allies, against Russian banks, oligarchs and state companies.

"Putin is the aggressor. Putin chose this war. And now he and his country will bear the consequences," he said.

In his address, Putin said he had ordered "a special military operation" to protect people, including Russian citizens, subjected to "genocide" in Ukraine - an accusation the West calls baseless propaganda.

"And for this we will strive for the demilitarisation and denazification of Ukraine," Putin said. read more

After nightfall, a picture was emerging of fierce fighting across multiple fronts. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy late on Thursday ordered a general mobilization, to be carried out within 90 days, "to ensure the defence of the state".

An adviser to the Ukrainian presidential office said Russian forces had captured the Chernobyl former nuclear power plant, just 90 km (60 miles) north of Kyiv. The plant is along the shortest route from the Ukrainian capital to Belarus, where Moscow has staged troops.

There was also fighting at Hostomel airport, just outside Kyiv, where Russian paratroopers landed. A Ukrainian official later said the airfield had been recaptured, while a senior U.S. defence official said Russian forces were advancing closer to Kyiv.

Heavy exchanges of fire were also reported in the regions of Sumy and Kharkiv in the northeast and Kherson in the south.

The highway heading west out of Kyiv, home to 3 million people, was choked with traffic across five lanes as residents sought to escape, fearful of bombardments while stuck in their cars.

The U.N. refugee agency said an estimated 100,000 Ukrainians had fled their homes. Thousands were crossing into neighbouring countries, including Romania, Moldova, Poland and Hungary. read more

Some 57 people were killed and 169 were wounded on Thursday, Ukraine's health minister said, while the interior ministry said 13 border guards died when a Russian vessel shelled Ukraine's Zmiinyi Island, south of the Black Sea port of Odessa.

'NEW IRON CURTAIN'

The day began with missiles raining down on targets across Ukraine and reports of troops and armour pouring across the borders from Russia and Belarus to the north and east.

Zelenskiy called on Ukrainians to defend their country and said arms would be given to anyone prepared to fight.

"What we have heard today are not just missile blasts, fighting and the rumble of aircraft. This is the sound of a new Iron Curtain, which has come down and is closing Russia off from the civilised world," Zelenskiy said.

Putin, after referring earlier in his speech to Russia's powerful nuclear arsenal, warned: "Whoever tries to hinder us... should know that Russia's response will be immediate. And it will lead you to such consequences that you have never encountered in your history."

Asked whether that threat was tantamount to threatening Russian use of nuclear weapons, Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said it was indeed understood as such, adding that Putin should also understand that NATO was a nuclear alliance.

Biden has ruled out sending U.S. troops to defend Ukraine, but Washington has reinforced its NATO allies in the region with extra troops and planes.

Putin, who denied for months that he was planning an invasion, has called Ukraine an artificial construct carved from Russia by its enemies - a characterisation Ukrainians see as an attempt to erase their more than 1,000-year-old history.

While many Ukrainians, particularly in the east, speak Russian as a native language, virtually all identify themselves as Ukrainian.

Crimea was originally part of Russia from 1783 until 1954 when the Soviet government transferred the region to the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic.

However no further information of the transfer was made available for the remainder of the Soviet Union, becoming available to the public in 1992 when the Union dissolved.

Around 120,00 refugees have fled Ukraine to neighbouring Poland, Moldova, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, the UN said. The largest numbers were arriving in Poland, where 2 million Ukrainians have already settled to work in recent years. At the Medyka border crossing, the line of vehicles waiting to enter Poland stretched 9 miles into Ukraine. Poland declared its border open to fleeing Ukrainians, as did Hungary. “We will help everyone,” the Polish Border Agency said. “We will not leave anyone without help.”

Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday spoke with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the Ukraine conflict and appealed for immediate cessation of violence as well as concerted efforts from all sides to return to the path of diplomatic negotiations.

During their telephonic conversation, President Putin briefed Prime Minister Modi about the recent developments regarding Ukraine, the Prime Minister's Office said in a statement.
